fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-35316].
  {panel}

We currently document our requirements in both Jira and Confluence. The process is that we first create sketches that we discuss and agree on, create the epic(s) and user stories in Jira, describe these as detailed as necessary, break them down, estimate and start the work. In the middle of this there is also an approval per issue to ensure that we haven't misunderstood each other along the way. 

Once the user stories are approved the requirements are transferred to Confluence for later reference - they are also "bound" together to make it easier to read as a whole if needed. 

What we would like is to write the descriptions fully in Confluence and tag them with anchors or similar, and then link these specific anchors from Jira. In this way we would only have to write the descriptions once, and we do not risk the possible differences between what is described in the two different systems. 

I know you can write something in Confluence, "mention" the Jira-issue and this way get a link between the two. But that would again require the developer to go back and forth, which is not very optimal for us.
fields.summary: As a user I would like to be able to link and show the contents from a Confluence page in the description of a Jira issue

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

1. Set up crowd with a directory which has mixed case groups
2. Configure JIRA application to use Crowd for auth
3. Check groups in JIRA to find them in the mixed case
4. Log into Crowd and enable the "Lower Case Output" option for the JIRA application then resync the user directory in JIRA
5. Check groups in JIRA to find them in the mixed case.
5.1 Expected: group names should be automatically updated to be in lower case
6. Remove the user directory in JIRA and verify the groups are gone within JIRA
7. Add the Crowd directory back
8. Check groups in JIRA to find them in lower case
9. Go into Crowd and disable the Lower Case Output option.
10. Sync JIRA directory and check groups names in JIRA, they are in lower case.
10.1 Expected: group names should be automatically updated to be in mixed case

Tested on Crowd  2.6.5 with JIRA 6.1
fields.summary: Updating the Lower Case Output option in crowd does not affect group names in JIRA

fields.description:
h4. Userstory
As a enterprise user, using bleeding edge unreleased IE version, I want to use JIRA deployed into our intranet, without seeing red error message saying *Internet Explorer 7.0 is not a supported browser*.
h4. To Reproduce
# way 1
## install JIRA to intranet domain address
## configure IE 11 to use compatibility mode for intranet sites
# way 2
## add your JIRA domain to compatibility mode sites list
# access JIRA
# now you should see red bar at the top of the page

h4. The Cause
This issue is cause by the fact, that when coding JIRA you had no idea what kind of user-agent string Microsoft would use for IE 11 and hence have no support for recognizing IE 11, when it's in compatibility mode.

h4. The Fix
I have added a .patch file with simple fix to detect if browser, that reports itself to be MSIE 7.0, is in fact IE 11.
Note, you might want to future proof yourself by detecting that Trident version is greater than 6.0 or 7.0 and decide, that this is in fact also IE that is newer than IE 11 and doesn't need warning about IE 7.0 not being supported.
fields.summary: JIRA does not recognize IE 11 in compatibility mode

  {panel}

With JIRA 6.1, edit any field configuration that has more than two dozen custom fields.
Try to find out which fields are required without scanning the list every field by hand.
Now try that with 300 custom fields!

In older versions of JIRA an admin could use the Find button in their browser to search for strings such as "Required" or "Hidden". The changes for 6.1 mean that the string to indicate whether a field is required is the same as the string for the link to *make* the field required. This means it's much harder to find which fields are required in a field configuration.
fields.summary: No way to find required fields in a Field Configuration except by inspection

*NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-35250].
{panel}
*Description*
 If the name of a project is same as the key of another project, then, when using JQL to search by name on the first project would retrieve all issues from the second project.
h4. First Symptom

*Steps to reproduce*
 1. Create the first project with name: *My Test Project*, key: *MTP*
 2. Create the second project with name *MTP*, key: *MP*
 3. Seach with advance JQL:
{code:java}
project ="MTP"{code}
4. All issues belong to *My Test Project* project are retrieved.

*Expected result*
 All issues belong to *MTP* project should be retrieved.
h4. Second Symptom

*Steps to reproduce*
 # create first project with name *My Test Project*, key: *MTP*
 # create second project with name *MTP*, key: *MP*
 # create a new JQL, insert:
{code:java}
project=MTP
{code}

 # select project with key *MP* from the suggested list
 # hit Enter and the issue for project with key "MTP" is return

*Expected Result*
 Issue for project with key "MP" is return as user manually select the project from the suggestion list

*Workaround*
 -Searching based on the Key, for example-  This workaround did not work for the case JST-531144.
{code:java}
project = MP{code}
fields.summary: Wrong filter result if project name duplicate with other project key

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-35240].
  {panel}

I have encountered a significant and unadvertised difficulty in accessing the REST API.

I am working on an iOS app, which consumes information programmatically but doesn't handle redirects and cookies--I'm not saying that there's not probably something out there, but the tried and true standby of accessing https://username:password@hostname/rest/api/2/foo . And after pulling out my hair after figuring out why my iOS code wasn't handling JSON appropriately, I tried something.

I entered, in a browser window, https://username:password@hostname/rest/api/2/foo , and two things happened:

1: The correct data was displayed, and:

2: The URL was retconned to https://hostname/rest/api/2/foo

The reason why I only got empty results was that a REST API pull of https://username:password@hostname/rest/api/2/foo does not behave as one would expect from a REST API, especially not one as simple and powerful as JIRA genuinely offers.

I'm pretty much dead in the water for my original approach to getting data. I can circumvent this issue by manually copying data from JIRA to static content on my own server, but that is a workaround to a development blocker, not a solution, even a cumbersome one, to real production usage. You might be able to help me work around this difficulty, but if you're going to advertise a RESTful API, it would be nice if you didn't practically defeat the REST standby of https://username:password@hostname/rest/api/2/foo

I'm open to learning cookies or whatever powers live human browser usage of your REST API, but your failure to support basic authentication over HTTPS had me pulling my hair out trying to figure out what I had done wrong in iOS to not let iOS handle your JSON properly.

I think a REST API with support for basic authentication would be a major improvement.
fields.summary: As a developer consuming REST API, I would like to get results when I pull data from https://username:password@hostname.atlassian.net/rest/api/2/foo

        at com.atlassian.jira.service.JiraServiceContainerImpl.run(JiraServiceContainerImpl.java:61)        at com.atlassian.jira.service.ServiceRunner.execute(ServiceRunner.java:48)
        at org.quartz.core.JobRunShell.run(JobRunShell.java:195)        at org.quartz.simpl.SimpleThreadPool$WorkerThread.run(SimpleThreadPool.java:520)
2013-10-09 18:57:14,011 QuartzScheduler_Worker-2 ERROR ServiceRunner    Generic Comment-from-email service [atlassian.mail.incoming.mailfetcherservice] Generic Comment-from-email service[10050]: Exception: null
java.lang.NullPointerException        at com.atlassian.jira.mail.MailThreadManagerImpl.parseIssueFromMessageId(MailThreadManagerImpl.java:316)
        at com.atlassian.jira.mail.MailThreadManagerImpl.getAssociatedIssueFromMessageId(MailThreadManagerImpl.java:286)        at com.atlassian.jira.mail.MailThreadManagerImpl.getAssociatedIssueObject(MailThreadManagerImpl.java:207)
        at com.atlassian.jira.plugins.mail.handlers.AbstractMessageHandler.getAssociatedIssue(AbstractMessageHandler.java:1393)        at com.atlassian.jira.plugins.mail.handlers.CreateOrCommentHandler.handleMessage(CreateOrCommentHandler.java:74)
        at com.atlassian.jira.service.services.mail.MailFetcherService$1.process(MailFetcherService.java:400)        at com.atlassian.jira.service.services.mail.MailFetcherService$MessageProviderImpl.getAndProcessMail(MailFetcherService.java:293)
        at com.atlassian.jira.service.services.mail.MailFetcherService.runImpl(MailFetcherService.java:388)
        at com.atlassian.jira.service.services.file.AbstractMessageHandlingService.run(AbstractMessageHandlingService.java:257)
        at com.atlassian.jira.service.JiraServiceContainerImpl.run(JiraServiceContainerImpl.java:61)
        at com.atlassian.jira.service.ServiceRunner.execute(ServiceRunner.java:48)
        at org.quartz.core.JobRunShell.run(JobRunShell.java:195)
        at org.quartz.simpl.SimpleThreadPool$WorkerThread.run(SimpleThreadPool.java:520)
{code}

This appears to be caused by either of the following scenarios:

* We could not find an issue with the id specified in the email in JIRA (possibly caused by issues being deleted). This should be ok as there's no issue to update. However, it kind of sucks for the user replying to the email as they have no idea that the issue he's replying to is gone from JIRA so his update was not processed successfully. Having said that, I see no easy way around that.
* The issue has a 'null' created date. This is a data integrity issue, as all issues should have a created date, but we should definitely handle the scenario better. In this case, the issue that was replied to in the email will not be updated by the handler.

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Attempting to use mentions in IE8 results in incorrect WML being inserted into the comment.

h3. Environment

* IE8

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Mention someone in a comment using IE8.
# Click on the results.

h3. Expected Results

The correct WML is inserted, e.g.:
{noformat}
[~admin]
{noformat}

h3. Actual Results

The below WML is inserted:

{noformat}
[~admin]admin
{noformat}

h3. Workaround

Using the keyboard to select the results will enter the correct WML.
fields.summary: Mentions broken in IE8

fields.description:
When attempting to import a project to our jira test environment from a jira instance with the same build #, I receive the following error
'This data appears to be from an older version of JIRA. Please upgrade the data and try again. The current version of JIRA is at build number '6144', but the supplied backup file was for build number '6106'.'
Even though the site is in fact using build 6144

I have even exported the jira test environment and attempted to import a project back into jira test only to receive the same error.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Export from JIRA instance running version 6.1 with build 6144 using Backup System
2. Move the export file to jira test instance directory /var/atlassian/application-data/jira/import/attachments
3. Attempt to import the entities.xml file usings Import Project
fields.summary: Project import in JIRA 6.1 failing due to incorrect build #
Upgrade DVCS Connector plugin to version 1.4.3 in OnDemand
Allow configuration for more in-depth SQL logs

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-35227].
  {panel}

We've recently upgraded to JIRA 6.0.8 from 5.2.11, and one of the first things my users noticed is that the width of the Text and Free Text fields (including the built-in ones like _Summary_ and _Description_) has been reduced significantly on Create and Edit forms.

In general, we love the new interface, but this specific example is causing some pain, as the UI now makes it more difficult to enter large amounts of text.  Also, unlike in previous releases, the "max-width" property is being set for these fields, meaning that users aren't allowed to enlarge the text boxes for Free Text fields in browsers that provide that capability (like Chrome).  This is triggering a lot of "workaround" behaviour, where people are using other tools to write their text, and then pasting it into the JIRA form...this is not a good model, as it is very error-prone.

My users noticed that the new widths are being equally applied to the static Create and Edit forms, as on the QuickCreate and QuickEdit forms, even though the static forms have much more room to work with.  This used to be the favoured approach by those that didn't like the smaller fields on the QuickCreate/QuickEdit forms, but there is no longer any difference between the forms.

Currently, these fields are being styled with the "long-field" class.  This request is to re-classify these fields as "full-width-field", which does not set the max-width attribute.
fields.summary: Please use "full-width-field" style for Text and Free Text fields

fields.description:
IF I link Jira issue A to Jira issue B with a "Depends on" link, then Jira B shows that it "is dependent on" Jira A.  It isn't.
"is dependent on" means the same as "depends on", not the opposite.
fields.summary: "Depends on" link gives misleading wording

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-35224].
  {panel}

Many of our customers come to our team and ask for change their workflow.
Currently we have lots of workflows in our Jira.

How about some small search feature for workflows.

- Select statuses your customer is interested in.
- Jira displays only matching workflows with this statuses.
- Jira displays images of the workflows (because an image is a thousand words and it is easier to see the difference)
- You may zoom in (pop-up) an image with workflow
- Select desired one and have popup with a question to which Issue Types assign to (automaticly create workflow scheme)
fields.summary: Workflow search

fields.description:
On My Dashboard screen I have few views with all issues assigned to me, issues assigned to me that are in progress and all issues that should be fixed in current fix version and are not closed or canceled.

The problem is that the views include IFRAMEs and JavaScript reloading/refreshing these iframes does not adjust the height of the view accordingly. This results in not seeing all the issues (if some has been added to the concrete view) or in an empty space after the list of issues in the view.

The only solution how to solve this is to: 
# click on "More" on the view's header bar, 
# click on "Edit" and then 
# *Cancel* the edit (as clicking on *Save* will result in no change at all). 

After this bothering steps the view is re-rendered with height set up accordingly.

I am attaching 4 screens, each containing two views:
# second view is smaller than the list of issues
# after the sequence of steps described above the view is re-rendered
# first view is now bigger (3 tasks were closed) - after clicking on "Refresh" only the issues are refreshed, view remains the same height as if there were 8 issues (as before)
# after the sequence of steps described above the view is re-rendered

This is really annoying so fixing this would be highly appreciated.
fields.summary: JIRA - My Dashboard - views does not adjust their height automatically

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-35220].
  {panel}

When pressing either the dot or the comma when I'm in the detail screen of an issue, the same dialog is shown containing a mix of Issue/Workflow Operations and Edit Field Operations.

In my opinion, these actions should display two separate dialog's. 
* The dot dialog should only display Issue/Workflow Operations
* The comma dialog should only display Edit Field Operations.

This difference used to be there in pre 6.0 versions of JIRA. In the current setup, additional keyboard actions are required to, for example, assign an issue via a workflow action. When pressing the dot, and typing *assign*, the edit field action is selected first, in this case however, I want to perform the specified workflow action and have to choose this manually using the arrow keys.

Could the two dialog's please be separated again?

Kind regards,
Sander Moelands
fields.summary: dot en comma shortcuts show the same dialog

fields.description:
One of the customers reported that for large instances it's not possible to cancel re-indexing after project key was changed. Either the process checks for cancellation rarely or it doesn't check for it at the project re-index level at all.

I imagine problem is caused by jira.index.background.batch.size (advanced property) set to some large value - issues are processed in batches and when batch is processed it's not possible to cancel (the flag is set but cancellation happens only between batches).
fields.summary: It's not possible to cancel re-indexing after Project Key Rename

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-35218].
  {panel}

h3. Summary

Projects with long names are cut off in the create issue screen as the project drop-down is only 250px.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Create a project with a long name.
# Create an issue.

h3. Expected Results

The drop down has sufficient space to display the project name.

h3. Actual Results

The project name is cut off as per the example.

h3. Notes

This could be fixed by extending the 250px width to 500px which would be sufficient and also kinda lines up with the rest of the page.

h3. Workaround

* The JIRA files could be altered to change the display of the drop downs - if you'd like to do this please raise it on [Atlassian Answers|https://answers.atlassian.com/] as it's unsupported - see a sample CSS fix in the [comment below|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-35218?focusedCommentId=622714&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-622714].
* Note that you should be able to see the project name in full, by hovering your mouse over each project name from the drop-down list.
* The project name can be shortened so that it correctly appears.
fields.summary: Project drop down in Create Issue screen cuts off long project names

fields.description:
After a JIRA upgrade from 4.1 to 4.4.5 and a LDAP integration, dashboards and filters are lost. After analyse into JIRA database, it is due to uppercase/lowercase mismatch. Favourite associations from JIRA 4.1 had lowercase username attribute whereas it is username in JIRA 4.4 (user_name attribute from cwd_user table is inserted into favouriteassociation table instead of lower_user_name).

Now, some LDAP (Microsoft AD integration with synchronization) user who have UPPERCASE username cannot retrieve their favourite dashboards and filters.
fields.summary: favourite associations are based on user_name instead of lower_user_name attribute
